page.title: 01INTRODUCTION
page.content: Blackpool's first mention in official documents came in 1602, as a part of the parish of Bispham. It received its name from the dark, peaty stream which flowed out of Marton Mere to the sea. In the 18th century, when sea bathing became fashionable, a road was laid across the marshes between Preston and the coast, and stage coaches brought visitors to stay in the cottages on the shoreline. In 1840, a railway line was opened through Poulton to Fleetwood and visitors went by cart from Poulton to the sea and back. In 1846 a line was opened to North Shore, Blackpool, and Blackpool developed into the holiday resort for the working people of the industrial North.
